info.game_comments:
2004 Power Players Week game 5.
From Washington, D.C.
Senator John McCain reads Final Jeopardy!

(1, 1).clue: In 1971 Daniel Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers to this newspaper's Neil Sheehan

(2, 1).clue: This Dickens character is the first full name mentioned in J.D. Salinger's "Catcher in the Rye"

(3, 1).clue: The ocean current named for this most populous state flows south at a slow, you might also say mellow, pace

(4, 1).clue: Of $3.75, $5.15 or $7.25, the current federal minimum hourly wage

(5, 1).clue: This 4th century B.C. Macedonian king supposedly "wept, for there were no more worlds to conquer"

(6, 1).clue: You might've noticed this 132-room building on an 18-acre plot a few doors down

(1, 2).clue: This 108-year-old magazine that covers hunting & fishing is "The soul of the American outdoors"

(2, 2).clue: This legendary frontiersman's motto was "Be always sure you're right--then go ahead!"

(3, 2).clue: Blend the north & south equatorial currents, add a splash from west of Florida & you've got this "stream"

(4, 2).clue: The value of all goods & services produced within a country during a year makes up this, the GDP

(5, 2).clue: In 1949 this country legend sang, "The midnight train is whining low, I'm so lonesome I could cry"

(6, 2).clue: "Earthy" term for an overwhelming election victory

(1, 3).clue: The logo of this humorous newspaper is seen here

(2, 3).clue: In terms of electricity, it flows steadily in one direction

(3, 3).clue: A dip in the Arctic current named for this, the world's largest island, would certainly be invigorating

(4, 3).clue: Created in 1914, this agency issues cease & desist orders against firms engaging in unlawful practices

(1, 4).clue: This magazine has been giving its seal of approval since 1909

(2, 4).clue: This epic poem by Dante is divided into 3 sections: the Inferno, the Purgatorio & the Paradiso

(3, 4).clue: Spanish for "the child", it's the warm back eddy of the chilly Peru Current

(4, 4).clue: Its past chairmen have included Thomas McCabe, Arthur Burns & Paul Volcker

(1, 5).clue: It calls itself "The newspaper of Capitol Hill since 1955"

(3, 5).clue: The Falkland Current flows for hundreds of miles up the east coast of this country

(4, 5).clue: The full title of Adam Smith's monumental 1776 work is "An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of" this

(1, 1).clue: In California, February 6, 2004 was proclaimed this president's "Day" in honor of his 93rd birthday

(2, 1).clue: Exit 61B: I may be conservative on the Supreme Court but take me hunting & I shoot liberally

(3, 1).clue: Sexy nickname of Major Margaret Houlihan on "M*A*S*H"

(4, 1).clue: Poised to unseat Bill Gates as numero uno is this Berkshire Hathaway man, now ranked No. 2

(5, 1).clue: If you're genuphobic, you're afraid of these lower body parts that bend

(6, 1).clue: In 1905 at his house in Switzerland, this German physicist wrote his theory of relativity

(1, 2).clue: He was the fifth Harvard grad to become president, & the first Roman Catholic

(2, 2).clue: I'm on first, Exit 102.  What's on second?  My partner Costello, Exit 155P

(3, 2).clue: When business is good, things are "selling like" these pan-fried foods

(4, 2).clue: The Donald tied for No. 205 with the Steven--this director

(5, 2).clue: If you've got musophobia, you may yell "Eek!" on seeing one of these small animals

(6, 2).clue: Splitting atoms to release energy is called fission; combining atoms to release energy is called this

(1, 3).clue: His presidential library sells aprons with the motto "If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen"

(2, 3).clue: Born off the Ohio Pike:I invented so much stuff in N.J. they named a township for me (take Exit 10 & 287)

(3, 3).clue: As a verb, it means to perform difficult stunts; as a noun, it's something you eat at the ballpark

(4, 3).clue: 5 members of this retail family made the Top 10, including Jim & John (shouldn't that be Jim-Bob & John-Boy?)

(5, 3).clue: Gephyrophobia is a fear of crossing these structures & we'll do it when we come to it

(6, 3).clue: Chemical symbol U, this metallic element is used as a fuel in nuclear reactors & weapons

(1, 4).clue: At over 330 pounds, you might say this Wilson predecessor had a huge impact on the presidency

(2, 4).clue: Exit 100B down the shore: You're in for a beat-down if you don't know I'm the male actor with the most Oscar nominations

(3, 4).clue: To start a car by short-circuiting the ignition

(4, 4).clue: Ironically, Dhanin Chearavanont made a fortune with this kind of "feed", slang for a small amount of money

(5, 4).clue: If you've got dendrophobia, a fear of these, you probably can't see the forest for them

(1, 5).clue: Of the first 5 U.S. presidents, he was the only one who wasn't born in Virginia

(3, 5).clue: A heated building usually with glass walls where delicate plants are raised

(4, 5).clue: There's no potter's field in the future for this creator of Harry Potter; she's No. 552

(5, 5).clue: Hopefully Noah didn't have antlophobia, a fear of these natural disasters

(0, 0).clue: In the year 1958, the U.S. Senate was made up of this many members
